text:
HAZEL SIVE: After
your assignment,

you should know the
following about pedigrees.

You should be able to pick
out an autosomal recessive,

an autosomal dominant, or an
x-linked recessive pedigree.

And you should know
also the nomenclature.

You should be able
to look at a pedigree

and remember what the
filled-in and the not-filled-in

and the various
different symbols mean,

and then you'll be
well on your way

to doing more complex
pedigree analysis.

What we've talked about
today has been a whole bunch.

We've talked, really, about
changes in DNA and the traits--

the phenotypes-- that are
associated with these changes.

We've talked about actually
knowing what the changes are,
as in mutations.

We've talked about different
variations of genes,

as in alleles and how these
segregate during meiosis.

And we've talked about how
the gametes that come out

of meiosis are then used to
carry out genetic crosses that

let us understand something
more about the characteristics

of the inheritance
of various traits.

And finally, we've
talked about cases

where it's very difficult to
know what gene is involved,

in which case we use analysis of
pedigrees to help enlighten us.
